descriptions.examine: A simple wooden mailbox. The word "WELCOME" is painted on the side in cheerful letters.
descriptions.read:
You unfold the letter and read:

"Hey! Welcome to gtm.consulting.

Most consultants give you a pitch deck. I made you an adventure.

If you're here, you're probably wondering how AI actually transforms executive work -- not in theory, but in practice. Not in jargon, but in joy.

Explore. Have fun. Type HELP if you get stuck.

I'm excited to see where you go.

- Justin"
descriptions.open: You open the mailbox. There's a letter inside. (Try: READ LETTER)

descriptions.examine: A weathered rowboat, half-filled with sand. It's seen better days — one oar is missing and the hull has a crack running down the side. You could climb in.
A rusty metal toolbox. There's a sticker on the lid — a fancy-looking robot with glowing eyes and a sly grin.
descriptions.open: You pop the latch and open the toolbox. Inside, nestled in a greasy rag, there's a screwdriver.

descriptions.examine: A well-worn Phillips screwdriver. The handle has a small sticker — the same fancy robot logo as the toolbox.
A sun-bleached oar, cracked but still solid. It leans against the gunwale like it's been waiting for someone.
descriptions.take: It's wedged in pretty good. Better to leave it.

descriptions.examine: Grapevines. Thick, tangled grapevines loaded with dark fruit. They block the path deeper into the forest, but through small gaps you can see light flickering on the other side. The passage is impassable, but the grapes look ripe.
A worn welcome mat that reads "Make Yourself at Home" in faded letters.
descriptions.move: You lift the corner of the mat and find a small brass key!
descriptions.lift: You lift the corner of the mat and find a small brass key!
descriptions.look: You lift the corner of the mat and find a small brass key!

descriptions.examine: A small brass key. It looks like it might fit the back door.
One of the cabin's windows is slightly ajar, just enough that you might be able to open it further.
descriptions.open: With a bit of effort, you push the window open wide enough to climb through.
descriptions.enter: You climb through the window and land softly inside.

descriptions.examine: A sturdy wooden back door. It appears to be locked.
descriptions.examine_unlocked: A sturdy wooden back door, now unlocked.
descriptions.unlock: You insert the key and hear a satisfying click. The door is now unlocked!
descriptions.unlock_nokey: The door is locked. You'll need a key.
descriptions.open: You open the door and step inside.

descriptions.examine: A portrait of a man with an easy smile. Below the frame, a small plaque reads "Justin Strackany, Founder."
descriptions.read:
I'm Justin Strackany. I spent 18 years building and scaling customer success orgs, including serving as Chief Customer Officer at SecureLink through three exits.

Now I help executives and their teams actually use AI -- not implement it for show, but integrate it into how they think, decide, and create.

Most people are drowning in AI tools. I help you swim.

descriptions.examine: An old rotary phone sits on a small table. It has a satisfying weight to it. There's a small drawer in the table beneath it.
descriptions.use:
You pick up the receiver. There's a crackle, then a voice — warm, unhurried:

"Hello! It's Justin. Well, a recording of Justin. The real one is probably drinking coffee somewhere.

Listen — if you've made it this far, you're my kind of person. Most people don't get past the mailbox.

If you want to leave me a message, just SAY whatever's on your mind. I'll hear it.

Or if you'd rather talk for real, check the drawer."

The line stays open, waiting.
descriptions.open:
You open the drawer and find a business card with clean, simple text:

"Ready to talk?
Book a conversation: calendly.com/justinstrackany

Or just reply to whatever email brought you here.

No pitch deck. No pressure. Just a conversation about what's possible."
descriptions.close: You place the receiver back on the cradle. The line goes quiet.

descriptions.examine: A simple wall clock. The hands are frozen at 11:11. Something about that feels... intentional.
A shabby rug, threadbare in places, covering most of the floor. One corner is slightly upturned, as if something underneath is pushing it up.
descriptions.move: You pull the rug aside and reveal a heavy trapdoor set into the floor! Iron bands reinforce the edges, and a modern keypad lock glows softly — four digits, waiting for input.
descriptions.lift: You pull the rug aside and reveal a heavy trapdoor set into the floor! Iron bands reinforce the edges, and a modern keypad lock glows softly — four digits, waiting for input.
descriptions.look: You peer under the upturned corner and see... metal. There's something under this rug. Try pulling it aside.
descriptions.take: It's too big and too shabby to be worth taking.

coded_door.name: trapdoor

descriptions.examine: A heavy trapdoor set into the floor, reinforced with iron bands. A modern keypad lock glows softly — four digits, waiting for input. Stone steps descend into darkness below.
descriptions.use: The keypad awaits a 4-digit code. Try entering a number.

coded_door.codeSuccess: The keypad beeps cheerfully. You hear a heavy click, and the trapdoor swings open. Stone steps lead down.
coded_door.codeFail: The keypad beeps sadly. That's not the right code.

descriptions.examine: The front door is solidly boarded shut from the outside. Heavy planks are nailed across it in an X pattern. Whoever did this really didn't want anyone getting in this way.
descriptions.open: You push against the door, but the boards hold firm. It's not budging.
descriptions.kick: You give the door a solid kick. The boards rattle but hold. Your foot hurts now.
descriptions.break: You'd need a lot more than bare hands to break through those boards.
descriptions.knock: You knock on the boarded door. The sound is muffled by the planks. No one answers.
descriptions.pull: You try pulling at the boards, but they're nailed tight. You'll need tools to get these off.
descriptions.push: You push against the door, but the boards hold firm. It's not budging.
descriptions.use: There's no way through this door. The boards are solid.

descriptions.examine: Heavy wooden planks nailed in an X pattern across the door. The nails are rusted but holding strong.
descriptions.pull: You try pulling at the boards, but they're nailed tight. You'd need a crowbar or something similar.
descriptions.break: You try to break the boards with your bare hands. They don't even budge. You'll need tools.
descriptions.remove: The boards are nailed too securely. You'd need proper tools to remove them.
descriptions.take: They're nailed to the door frame. You can't just take them.

descriptions.examine: A dense forest stretches to the south. The trees grow thick and dark, but a narrow path winds between them. You could go that way.

A beautiful chess set, carved from dark and light wood. The pieces are arranged mid-game — a complex position where both sides have chances.

As you reach for the board, the air thickens. You sense someone across the table — stocky, crew cut, the ghost of black coffee on his breath.

Sit down?
descriptions.ghost:
A beautiful chess set. The pieces are frozen mid-game. As you approach, the chair across from you seems occupied — a flicker, like heat haze.

You feel the weight of someone's gaze.
descriptions.played: The chess set sits quiet. The chair across from you is empty now. Tommy's gone. You had your chance.
descriptions.read:
A small card reads: "Tommy Flores. VP of Operations. Meridian Logistics."

Below, in different handwriting: "45 days."

descriptions.examine:
A well-used dartboard. Three darts cluster near the bullseye — someone here doesn't miss.

As you step closer, you hear a nervous laugh. A woman sits at the table beside the board, notebook open, pen tapping. She looks up with bright eyes and maybe a little too much energy.

Sit down?
descriptions.ghost: The dartboard. Three darts, tight cluster. The chair beside it feels warm, like someone just stood up. You catch the faint scent of African violet.
descriptions.played: The dartboard hangs still. Reena's laugh has faded. The notebook is closed. You had your chance.
descriptions.read:
A scorecard reads: "Reena Okafor. Director of Customer Success. FinPulse."

Below: "3 weeks."

descriptions.examine:
An intricate puzzle, half-completed. The image emerging is a system architecture diagram — boxes, arrows, dependencies.

A monitor flickers on the desk beside it. A guy in a black t-shirt sits with his feet up, mechanical keyboard on his lap. He doesn't smile. Doesn't frown. Just looks at you.

Sit down?
descriptions.ghost: The puzzle. Half-finished architecture diagram. The desk lamp is on and you can see terminal output scrolling on the monitor. Someone was here moments ago.
descriptions.played: The puzzle sits half-done. The monitor is dark. Deck logged off. You had your chance.
descriptions.read:
A sticky note reads: "Deckard Morrison. Head of Revenue Ops. Vaultline."

Below, in tight handwriting: "60 days. Bake-off."

descriptions.examine:
A pristine deck of cards in a complex solitaire layout. Every option visible, nothing left to chance.

A woman sits at the desk behind the cards — back straight, reading glasses on, reviewing a document. She takes off her glasses and regards you with steady blue eyes.

Sit down?
descriptions.ghost: The cards. Perfect solitaire layout. The desk behind them has a coffee mug — chipped, reads 'I Survived Y2K.' A framed photo faces away from you.
descriptions.played: The cards lie still. Maggie's chair is empty, her reading glasses folded on the desk. You had your chance.
descriptions.read:
A card reads: "Margaret Whitfield. COO. Elara Health Systems."

Below, in precise handwriting: "30 days. Third CEO."

descriptions.examine: A heavy bronze challenge coin. One side shows the Marine Corps emblem. The other side is engraved: "2nd Battalion, 1st Marines. Fallujah. 2004." It's been handled so many times the edges are smooth.
A Memphis Grizzlies mug. The coffee inside is stone cold. Looks like it's been sitting here a while. Tommy drinks it black — you can tell by the ring stains.
A collection of African violets on the windowsill, each in a small ceramic pot. They're well-tended — clearly someone's quiet ritual. The newest one has a handwritten label: "Patience."
A notebook filled with crossed-out lines. Lists, mostly. Budget numbers, vendor names, pros and cons. The handwriting gets more erratic toward the bottom of each page, like the thinking got harder.
descriptions.read: The visible page has two columns: KEEP and CUT. Your company's name appears in the KEEP column, but with a question mark next to it. Below, in smaller writing: "How do I justify this?"

descriptions.examine: A black bass guitar, scuffed and worn in all the right places. The kind of instrument that's been on tour. A sticker on the body reads "SEVERED CONTRACT" in angular punk lettering. There are new strings on it — someone still plays.

A child's drawing taped to the monitor. A house with a blue door. Two stick figures — one tall, one small — holding hands under a yellow sun. "DADDY + ME" in crayon, the letters getting bigger toward the end like she ran out of paper.
A framed photo of a man with kind eyes and a gentle smile. He's wearing a battered Seiko watch. The frame is polished — someone touches it often.

A coffee mug, chipped at the rim, that reads "I Survived Y2K." Twenty-six years old and still in daily rotation. There's a faint lipstick mark on the rim. The coffee inside is half-finished — someone left in a hurry.
A low shelf holds a few dog-eared books. Nothing special catches your eye.
descriptions.examine_personalized: A low shelf holds a few dog-eared books. One stands out — your name, {name}, is embossed on the cover in gold leaf.
descriptions.read: You flip through the books. Business strategy, a dog-eared copy of 'The Hard Thing About Hard Things,' and a few others. Nothing personal.
descriptions.read_personalized:
You open the book with your name on it. Inside the front cover, a handwritten inscription:

"For {name} —

I wrote this after spending time with your work. Consider it a thank-you for being interesting.

— Justin"

You turn the page and begin reading:

{executive_summary}

---

P.S. If any of this resonates — or if I got something wrong — I'd love to hear about it.

Book a conversation: calendly.com/justinstrackany
Or just reply to whatever brought you here.

descriptions.examine: A thick envelope made of cream-colored paper. 'Your name' is written on the front in ornate calligraphy. The seal is broken — it's been waiting for you.
descriptions.examine_personalized: A thick envelope made of cream-colored paper. '{name}' is written on the front in ornate calligraphy. The seal is broken — it's been waiting for you.
descriptions.read:
You unfold the letter inside.

"Hey friend,

If you're reading this, you've made it past the locked door, the trapdoor code, and into the game room. Nice work.

Here's the deal: there are four rooms down here. In each one, a customer is waiting — someone with a real problem, a ticking clock, and a story they'll only tell if you ask the right questions.

You get five questions per room, twenty total. Spend them wisely.

When you're done with one, come back here and pick another door. Head upstairs when you're ready — there's a book on the shelf with your name on it. Check the back page before you leave.

And if you find the phone... well, say what you need to say.

Good luck.

— Justin"
descriptions.read_personalized:
You unfold the letter inside.

"Hey {name},

If you're reading this, you've made it past the locked door, the trapdoor code, and into the game room. Nice work.

Here's the deal: there are four rooms down here. In each one, a customer is waiting — someone with a real problem, a ticking clock, and a story they'll only tell if you ask the right questions.

You get five questions per room, twenty total. Spend them wisely.

When you're done with one, come back here and pick another door. Head upstairs when you're ready — there's a book on the shelf with your name on it. Check the back page before you leave.

And if you find the phone... well, say what you need to say.

Good luck.

— Justin"

descriptions.examine: A folded letter on the corner of the table, written on thick ivory paper. The handwriting is loose and unhurried — someone took their time.
descriptions.examine_personalized: A folded letter on the corner of the table, written on thick ivory paper. "{first_name}" is written on the front in careful, unhurried handwriting.
descriptions.read:
You unfold the letter.

"Hey friend,

If you made it this far, you're not the kind of person who skips to the answer.

The four people in these rooms are composites of real customers I've worked with. Real stakes, real pressure, real moments where the right question changed everything.

You have five questions per room and twenty total. Spend them wisely — or recklessly. I won't judge.

When you're done with one, come back here and pick another door. Or don't. It's your adventure.

This isn't about scoring points. It's about listening.

Good luck down here.

— Justin"
descriptions.read_personalized:
You unfold the letter.

"Hey {first_name},

I made this for you. Not a deck, not a case study — something you actually have to engage with.

The four people in these rooms are composites of real customers I've worked with. You're {role} at {company} — I know the kind of conversations you're in every day. These will feel familiar.

You have five questions per room and twenty total. Spend them wisely — or recklessly. I won't judge.

When you're done with one, come back here and pick another door. Or don't. It's your adventure.

This isn't about scoring points. It's about listening — really listening — the way you have to when the renewal is on the line and the customer hasn't told you what's actually wrong yet.

I think you'll be good at this.

— Justin"

descriptions.examine: The back of the book. There seems to be something written in pencil on the inside back cover.
descriptions.read: You flip to the back cover. The pages are blank.
descriptions.read_personalized:
You flip to the inside of the back cover. In barely visible pencil, someone has written:

"{secret_message}"

What an odd thing to write in a book. Maybe someone needs to hear this message?
